title: Walker County, Texas
text:
Walker County is a <a href="County%20%28United%20States%29">county</a> located in the east central section of the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Texas">Texas</a>. As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a>, its population was 67,861. Its <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> is <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Texas">Huntsville</a>. Initially, Walker County was named for <a href="Robert%20J.%20Walker">Robert J. Walker</a>, a legislator from <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a> who introduced into the <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a> the resolution to annex Texas. Walker later supported the U.S. during its Civil War and earned some enmity for it. In order to keep the county's name, the state renamed it for <a href="Samuel%20H.%20Walker">Samuel H. Walker</a> (no relation), a <a href="Texas%20Ranger%20Division">Texas Ranger</a> and soldier in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>.
Walker County comprises the Huntsville <a href="Micropolitan%20Statistical%20Area">Micropolitan Statistical Area</a> which is part of the <a href="Houston">Houston</a>–<a href="The%20Woodlands%2C%20Texas">The Woodlands</a> <a href="Greater%20Houston">Combined Statistical Area</a>.
Americans James Mitchell (1795–1870) and his wife, the former Calpernia Franklin (1805–1865), immigrated to the future Walker County in 1833 and were awarded a <a href="Mexico">Mexican</a> land grant. Mitchell, who became one of the first county commissioners, established the Mitchell House and Inn on the <a href="Old%20San%20Antonio%20Road">Old San Antonio Road</a>, also known as El Camino Real. During the 1840s, the house was a stop for weary and hungry <a href="stagecoach">stagecoach</a> travelers.
Geography.
According to the <a href="U.S.%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, the county has a total area of , of which is land and (2.2%) is water.
Demographics.
As of the census of 2000, there were 61,758 people, 18,303 households, and 11,384 families residing in the county. The population density was 78 people per square mile (30/km2). There were 21,099 housing units at an average density of 27 per square mile (10/km2). The racial makeup of the county was 69.12% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">white</a>, 23.88% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">black</a> or <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.35% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.77% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.05% <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 4.42% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.41% from two or more races. 14.11% of the population were <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race.
There were 18,303 households, out of which 28.70% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 46.80% were married couples living together, 11.70% had a female householder with no husband present, and 37.80% were non-families. 27.00% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.00% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.44 and the average family size was 3.02.
In the county, the population was spread out, with 18.00% under the age of 18, 23.00% from 18 to 24, 31.10% from 25 to 44, 18.90% from 45 to 64, and 8.90% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 31 years. For every 100 females, there were 151.10 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 161.90 males.
The median income for a household in the county was $31,468, and the median income for a family was $42,589. Males had a median income of $27,634 versus $22,579 for females. The per capita income for the county was $14,508. About 10.60% of families and 18.40% of the population were below the poverty line, including 19.10% of those under age 18 and 13.40% of those age 65 or over.
Education.
<a href="Sam%20Houston%20State%20University">Sam Houston State University</a> is located in <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Texas">Huntsville</a>.
School districts serving portions of the county include:
The <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20Trades%20Center">Gulf Coast Trades Center</a>, a charter school, is in an unincorporated area of the county.
The Huntsville and New Waverly ISDs are assigned to <a href="Lone%20Star%20College">Lone Star College</a>. Areas of Walker County in Trinity ISD are assigned to <a href="Angelina%20College">Angelina College</a>. The portion of Richards ISD in Walker County is zoned to <a href="Blinn%20College">Blinn College</a>.
Government and infrastructure.
The headquarters of the <a href="Texas%20Department%20of%20Criminal%20Justice">Texas Department of Criminal Justice</a> (TDCJ), the Texas agency that operates adult state correctional facilities, are in <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Texas">Huntsville</a>.
Walker County has the highest number of state prisons and jails of all of the counties in Texas. Several TDCJ prisons for men, including the <a href="Byrd%20Unit">Byrd Unit</a>, the <a href="Goree%20Unit">Goree Unit</a>, the <a href="Huntsville%20Unit">Huntsville Unit</a>, and the <a href="Wynne%20Unit">Wynne Unit</a>, are in the Huntsville city limits. The Holliday Unit, a transfer unit, is in Huntsville. In addition the <a href="Ellis%20Unit">Ellis Unit</a> and the <a href="Estelle%20Unit">Estelle Unit</a> are in <a href="unincorporated%20area">unincorporated area</a>s of Walker County. The Huntsville Unit houses the State of Texas execution chamber.
